      • What is the relationship between norms and inner products?

        Inner products induce norms. So you can use an inner product to make a norm. But some norms are not expressible as inner products.

      • What is an example of a norm that isn‚Äôt induced by an inner product?

        Say pi is your projection operation, pi(pi(x)) = pi(x).

        You can't double project.

      • What are 7 properties of determinants?
        1. det‚Å°(AB)=det‚Å°(A)det‚Å°(B)\det(\bm{AB}) = \det(\bm{A})\det(\bm{B})det(AB)=det(A)det(B)Ôªø
        1. det‚Å°(A)=det‚Å°(AT)\det(\bm{A}) = \det(\bm{A}^T)det(A)=det(AT)Ôªø
        1. det‚Å°(A‚àí1)=1det‚Å°(A)\det(\bm{A}^{-1}) = \frac{1}{\det(\bm{A})}det(A‚àí1)=det(A)1‚ÄãÔªø
        1. determinants of linear mappings, and other similar matrices are the same.
        1. subtracting or adding a multiple of another row/column to a row/column does not change the determinant.
        1. multiplying a row/column by a scalar multiplies the determinant by that scalar; so det‚Å°(ŒªA)=Œªndet‚Å°(A)\det(\lambda\bm{A}) = \lambda^n\det(\bm{A})det(ŒªA)=Œªndet(A)Ôªø.
        1. swapping 2 rows/columns changes the sign of the determinant.
      • What is the trace of a matrix?

        The sum of it‚Äôs diagonal elements.

      • What are 6 properties of traces?
        1. tr(A+B)=tr(A)+tr(B)\text{tr}(\bm{A} +\bm{B}) = \text{tr}(\bm{A}) + \text{tr}(\bm{B})tr(A+B)=tr(A)+tr(B)Ôªø
        1. tr(Œ±A)=Œ±‚ãÖtr(A)\text{tr}(\alpha\bm{A}) = \alpha\cdot\text{tr}(\bm{A})tr(Œ±A)=Œ±‚ãÖtr(A)Ôªø
        1. tr(In)=n\text{tr}(\mathbb{I}_n) = ntr(In‚Äã)=nÔªø
        1. tr(AB)=tr(BA)\text{tr}(\bm{AB}) = \text{tr}(\bm{BA})tr(AB)=tr(BA)Ôªø, A‚ààRn√ók,B‚ààRk√ón\bm{A} \in \R^{n\times k}, \bm{B} \in \R^{k\times n}A‚ààRn√ók,B‚ààRk√ónÔªø, applies to vectors too.
        1. cycles of matrix products all have the same trace, so long as the final product is square. tr(ABC)=tr(BCA)\text{tr}(\bm{ABC}) = \text{tr}(\bm{BCA})tr(ABC)=tr(BCA)Ôªø.
        1. traces of similar matrices are the same.

    • 4.2 Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors
      • What are co-directed and co-linear vectors?

        co-directed vectors are vectors that point in the same direction (positive scalar multiples of each other.

        co-linear vectors may point in opposite directions, and so are scalar multitples of each other.

      • What is the non-uniqueness of eigenvectors?

        if x\bm{x}xÔªø is an eigenvector, so is Œ±x, Œ±‚ààR\{0}\alpha\bm{x}, \ \alpha \in \R\backslash\{0\}Œ±x, Œ±‚ààR\{0}Ôªø.

      • What is the algebraic multiplicity of an eigenvalue?

        The number of eigenvalues with the same value.

      • What is eigenspace and eigenspectrum?

        eigenspace is span of the eigenvectors associates to one eigenvalue. Commonly it‚Äôs just 1 dimensional, but it could be more.

        Eigenspectrum, or just spectrum is the set of eigenvalues.

      • What are 4 properties of eigenvalues and eigenvectors?
        1. The eigenvalues of A\bm{A}AÔªø and AT\bm{A}^TATÔªø are the same, but the eigenvectors may not be.
        1. The eigenspace of an eigenvalue is also the nullspace of A‚àíŒªI\bm{A}-\lambda\mathbb{I}A‚àíŒªIÔªø.
        1. The eigenvalues of similar matrices are the same.
        1. Symmetric, posititve definite matrices have only positive, real eigenvalues.
      • How do you find eigenvectors and eigenspaces?

        By substituting your eigenvalue into

        and finding x\bm{x}xÔªø from there. The columns of x\bm{x}xÔªø comprise the eigenspace.

      • What is the geometric multiplicity of an eigenvalue?

        The dimension of the eigenspace of the eigenvalue.

        Can also think of it as the number of linearly independent eigenvectors of the eigenvalue.

        Always less than or equal to the algebraic multiplicity.

      • How does the determinant relate to the eigenvalues?

        The determinant is the product of the eigenvalues.

        Where Œªi\lambda_iŒªi‚ÄãÔªø are the eigenvalues of A\bm{A}AÔªø.

      • What does nnnÔªø distinct eigenvalues imply about the eigenvectors?

        There are nnnÔªø linearly independent eigenvectors.

      • What is a defective matrix?

        A matrix with fewer than nnnÔªø linearly independent vectors.

      • How can you obtain a positive, semidefinite matrix from any matrix?

        Let A‚ààRm√ón\bm{A} \in\R^{m\times n}A‚ààRm√ónÔªø.

      • How can you construct an ONB from a symmetric matrix?

        The eigenvectors of a symmetric matrix form an ONB. If the columns of the eigenspace of one eigenvalue are not orthogonal, you can use Gram-Schmidt orthogonalisation.

    • 4.3 Cholesky Decomposition

      • For which matrices does a SVD exist?

      • What makes SVD special in comparison to eigendecomposition?

        First it performs a basis change, then a scaling into a new vector space, then another basis change, whereas eigendecomposition only perfoms a basis change, scales and then undoes the basis change.

      • How is probability an extension of boolean logic?

        When we have many possible events followed by one another, we have that one event may affect the other in terms of probability. If it‚Äôs raining now, it‚Äôll probably be raining in 1 second from now, whereas boolean logic doesn‚Äôt have that nuance. In this sense probability extends boolean logic.

        1. You have P(Y‚â§y)P(Y \le y)P(Y‚â§y)Ôªø, which is FY(y)F_Y(y)FY‚Äã(y)Ôªø, a currently unknown function
        1. replace YYYÔªø with U(X)U(X)U(X)Ôªø
        1. Apply U‚àí1U^{-1}U‚àí1Ôªø to both sides
        1. now you have the cdf of x
        1. express it as a definite integral, with U‚àí1(y)U^{-1}(y)U‚àí1(y)Ôªø as the upper bound.
        1. Integrate it
        1. Now you have the cdf of YYYÔªø, which you know now.
        1. differentiate it to get the pdf

        Change-of-variables just gives you a straight up formula.

      • How would you rescale the step size given some criteria in each iteration?

        There are 2 ways of adaptively changing step size:

        1. If loss increases, go back and decrease step size
        1. If loss decreases, go back and increase step size, unless that increases loss.*

        *Bit dumb - better find where loss explodes and where training doesn‚Äôt happen and tune learning rate in that range.

      • What determines the speed of convergence for linear systems Ax=b\bm{Ax} = \bm{b}Ax=bÔªø

        The condition number

        You want it to be small.

    • 7.3 Convex Optimisation
      • What is a convex function?

        Finding the global minimum of fffÔªø, where

        for a scalar 0‚â§Œ∏‚â§10 \le \theta \le 10‚â§Œ∏‚â§1Ôªø.

      • What is a convex set?

        A set where the line between any 2 elements in the set is also in the set.

      • What is a concave function?

        The negative of a convex function.

      • What can we say about the gradient and the hessian of convex functions?

        For the gradient

        And f(x)f(\bm{x})f(x)Ôªø is convex if and only if the Hessian, ‚àáx2f(x)\nabla^2_{\bm{x}}f(\bm{x})‚àáx2‚Äãf(x)Ôªø, is positive semidefinite.

      • Is the non-negative weighted sum of 2 convex functions always convex?

        yah.

      • What is a supporting hyperplane?

        The hyperplane that makes a boundary for a constrained optimisation problem.

        It‚Äôs elements are in the convex set and the convex set is on one side of the hyperplane.

      • What is the Legendre-Fenchel interpretation of duality?

        Defines a convex function and space by hyperplanes, which are tangent to the convex set and hence can be defined as gradients of the objective function.

      • What is the definition of a convex conjugate?

        Usually the inner product is the dot product.

Part II - Machine Learning

  • Chapter 8 - When Models Meet Data
    • 8.1 Data, Models, and Learning
      • What makes a ‚Äúgood‚Äù neural network?

        One that performs well on the perfomance metrics we set for it.

        However this is a nuanced, somewhat philosophical question.

      • What are 3 non-conventional (tabular) applications of machine learning?
        1. Social media graphs
        1. Image-text pairs, like captioning
        1. Genomic sequences
      • What processing should you usually do to numerical data?

        Normalisation ‚Üí set each dimension to zero mean, unit variance w.r.t other examples.

      • What are features/attributes/covariates?

        Input elements; they‚Äôre different words for the same thing.

      • What is an example/data-point?

        An full input from the dataset. So a xn\bm{x}_nxn‚ÄãÔªø is a supervised training (xn,yn)(\bm{x}_n, \bm{y}_n)(xn‚Äã,yn‚Äã)Ôªø pair.

      • What is a label/target/response-variable/annotation?

        The known, true output; yn\bm{y}_nyn‚ÄãÔªø in the (xn,yn(\bm{x}_n, \bm{y}_n(xn‚Äã,yn‚ÄãÔªø) supervised training pair.

      • What are 2 views of a model? What is a predictor?

        A predictor is another word for a model.

        1. As a function f:RD1‚ÜíRD2f:\R^{D_1} \rightarrow \R^{D_2}f:RD1‚Äã‚ÜíRD2‚ÄãÔªø
        1. As a probabilistic model, essentially a pdf, which is just a special type of function, but we can apply probabilistic rules to it, like bayes rule.
      • What are 3 stages of machine learning algorithms?
        1. Parameter estimation
        1. Hyperparameter tuning
        1. Inference/testing
      • What is inference?

        Testing stage for probabilistic models.

        Sometimes can also mean parameter estimation or testing for non-probabilistic models.

      • What are 2 strategies for parameter estimation?
        1. Empirical risk minimisation - optimisation, numerical methods
        1. Maximum likelihood estimation - optimisation, probabilistic methods (Bayes‚Äô)
      • What is the philosophical term for training with regularisation?

        Abduction - Process of inference to the best explaination.

      • What is model selection?

        Tuning hyperparameters essentially.

    • 8.2 Empirical Risk Minimisation
      • What is the general formula for empirical risk minimisation?

        Where we have input X\bm{X}XÔªø and output y\bm{y}yÔªø and model fffÔªø. LLLÔªø is our loss function which is always non-negative and it calculates the difference between the labels yiy_i yi‚ÄãÔªø and our predictions y^i=f(xi)\hat{y}_i = f(\bm{x}_i)y^‚Äãi‚Äã=f(xi‚Äã)Ôªø.

      • What is the least squares problem?

        The solving of a linear classifier with squared-error loss using normal equations.

      • What is the expected (true) risk?

        The expected loss from the function fffÔªø over all possible* x,y\bm{x}, \bm{y}x,yÔªø.

        *Infinitely many.

      • What problem does regularisation solve?

        Solves* the problem of overfitting; by adding a term that penalises parameter size.

        *To an extent.

      • What is a penalty term?

        The regularisation term added to the loss.

      • What is the regulariser in probabilistic models?

        The prior, don‚Äôt ask me why.

      • What is (k-fold) cross validation?

        You have your data, you split it into KKKÔªø chunks.

        You use K‚àí1K-1K‚àí1Ôªø chunks for training and 1 chunk for validation.

        You use all KKKÔªø possible train-val combinations and get the average validation from there.

      • What is a con and pro of k-fold cross validation?

        Con: you train a bunch of networks.

        Pro: more accurate validation metric and is easily parallelizable so you can just run it quickly on multiple GPUs anyway.

        Multiply the likelihood by the prior.

        The prior is gaussian zero mean.

      • What are 4 properties of MLEs in ML?
        1. Can overfit easily (especially with ‚Äúsmall‚Äù datasets)
        1. Converges asymptotically as N‚Üí‚àûN \rightarrow \inftyN‚Üí‚àûÔªø
        1. Variance decreases as N‚Üí‚àûN \rightarrow \inftyN‚Üí‚àûÔªø, proportional to 1N\frac{1}{N}N1‚ÄãÔªø.
        1. Need a lot of data.
      • When does overfitting occur?

        When there are way more parameters than are needed to represent the data. See the graph below, of a sin graph estimated by different order polynomials.

      Introduces validation sets.

      • What tradeoffs do you get when choosing between a smaller and a larger model?

        Smaller datasets are less likely to overfit, but more likely to underfit; and vice versa.

        There‚Äôs an occum‚Äôs razor idea, where if we have smaller models, the space of datasets it can model is smaller, and so if our dataset is in such a dataset space then the probability of our model being the right one is better, but that‚Äôs an abstract SSTTRREETTCCHH in my opinion.
